message.content:
cs.CL, cs.SD, cs.HC, cs.AI, cs.LG 

This paper deals with natural language processing (NLP) and speech recognition, which are both subfields of computer science. The paper specifically focuses on creating a corpus for modeling word importance in spoken dialogue transcripts, which falls under the category of computational linguistics (cs.CL). Additionally, the paper discusses the potential applications of this corpus for evaluating automatic speech recognition (ASR) performance, which could fall under the categories of human-computer interaction (cs.HC), artificial intelligence (cs.AI), and machine learning (cs.LG). Finally, the paper also mentions the use of the corpus for creating metrics to predict ASR-output caption text usability for people who are deaf or hard-of-hearing, which could fall under the category of social and information networks (cs.SD).
